results.title: Growth: a study of Johnny and Jimmy. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Warden and Gilbert at Columbia University
results.brief_description: A study of the development of selected activities common to growing infants. Twin boys are selected and the influence of exercise on the development of each motor function at a number of age levels is studied. During the first 22 months Johnny is kept in a crib and then between the 22 to 25 month period was given intensive exercise. The complex interdependence of practice and maturation in development is illustrated. Reel 1: Development of creeping, development of the sitting position, development of erect locomotion, development in the assumption of an erect posture. Reel 2: A lure is suspended beyond the child’s reach in order to appraise his ability to manipulate pedestals so that he can climb up to obtain the object. Reel 3: in some behaviour activities not only attitude but also neuromotor performance are affected by exercise or restriction of funtion. The following are studies: Swimming behaviour and ascending inclines.

results.title: Growth of motor behaviour
results.brief_description: Short film in the Encyclopaedia Britannica series. Using Yale footage this shows motor or muscular development of a child between 4 weeks and 4 years through rolling, sitting, standing, walking and climbing stairs and riding a bike.

results.title: Growth of adaptive behaviour
results.brief_description: This short film shows the development of adaptive behaviour in a child staring at 15 weeks and going through to 4 years; mainly with crayons. Shows the child’s 4 year old drawing revealing the pattern of adaptive behaviour.

results.title: Growing up in New Guinea
results.brief_description: Looks at the lives the three indigenous New Guinea families through the eyes of a child from each family. The families range from stone-age primitive to partially civilised and fully civilised.

results.title: Growing together
results.brief_description: Parents of children aged from two to five years speak about the problems and joys of dealing with children at this age. Provides some insight into the nature of child development during this period. Companion film toe “One and one makes three”.

results.title: Group farming
results.creator_credit: Don Simmons and Australian Rural Adjustment Unit
results.brief_description: Considers the advantages and disadvantages of group farming. Discusses the issues involved in the sharing or pooling by farmers of resources such as machinery and sheds.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Simmons and Australian Rural Adjustment Unit

results.title: Grief
results.brief_description: Yonah, a taxi driver, wishes to bury his son who has committed suicide. But it is the start of the work day and there are not enough people at the funeral to form the requisite circle of mourners. We follow Yonah through the day and through the night, where after a series of encounters with a cross-section of urban Israelis, he returns by night to the grave site of his son. This subtle and exquisite Israeli film is itself a moving requiem for the relationship between a father and a son, and by extension, a lament for the contradictions and costs of the Jewish state.

results.title: Greetings from Wollongong
results.creator_credit: Mary Callaghan, Nina Saunders and Steel City Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in Wollongong on the south coast of New South Wales, the film chronicles a typical day in the lives of four teenagers. Faced with problems of unemployment, limited prospects and living in a city which is overrun by consumerist culture, they seek positive ways of constructing a life for themselves.

results.title: Greetings from Wollongong
results.brief_description: Four unemployed young people roam around one of Australia’s largest industrial cities. Combines social realist fiction with an essay-like examination of the city of Wollongong. This film is equally engaging and intellectually rigorous. As an exploration of a once leading steel-producing city, now increasingly blighted by unemployment, it also becomes a requiem for post-war working class Australia.

results.title: Greetings From Iraq
results.brief_description:
I was born in 1962 in a village on the Euphrates River near Najaf in Iraq. In 1985, I graduated with a degree in applied theatre studies from the Institute of Fine Arts in Baghdad. Shortly after completing my studies I went into exile in northern Iraq: I was waiting for political change to go back home. After crossing the border from Iraq to Iran, I was arrested, imprisoned and transferred to a detention centre. I remained there for seven weeks before I was transferred to another detention centre in Tehran. I was there for 11 months.
In the detention centre there was the constant threat of being deported back to Iraq. I got a false passport and was travelling to Syria when I was arrested again for having false papers.
I escaped to the Pakistan-Iran border; I introduced myself to UNHCR (United Nations High Commission for Refugees) as an Iraqi refugee. I spent - or wasted - seven years of my life waiting for an answer from the UNHCR regarding my application for resettlement.
I was finally accepted as a refugee by Australia. In 1997, I arrived in Perth. In 2001, I became an Australian citizen. In 2003, I finished my Master of Creative Arts at Newcastle University.
In 2004, I want back to see my homeland for the first time after 17 to 18 years in exile, afterwards returning to Australia.
- Niz Jabour

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004
